awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. As an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) center, CyberWatch has been addressing this workforce need for over a decade. In 2005, it was launched as an ATE regional center, with a focus on colleges and employers in the Washington-Baltimore region; and in 2012, it evolved into an ATE national center. The National CyberWatch Center (NCC) has achieved major national impact in cybersecurity education by establishing and validating education and training standards; creating a new annual conference focusing on cybersecurity education at the community college level; validating cybersecurity skills using performance-based assessments; and building new cybersecurity curricula tied to job roles and industry certifications.

In its next phase, the center will expand and enhance its leadership role by developing and promoting (1) programs and services designed to attract diverse populations into cybersecurity education and careers; (2) skills-based curricula; (3) collaborations among industry, government, and academia; (4) education, training, and assessment standards; and (5) other resources that increase the number of faculty members and colleges capable of offering high-quality courses and curricula in cybersecurity across the nation. One new focus will be to study and support students' transitions from two-year to four-year institutions in cybersecurity in order to increase the number of community college students who enroll in and complete CyberCorps: Scholarship for Service (SFS) programs.

por.por_cntn:
Building on its 18-year foundation of success, as evidenced by multiple successive ATE grants since 2005, its network of excellence, innovative programs, and far-reaching support services the National CyberWatch Center created and honed was essential to bringing cybersecurity education to academic institutions, employers, and the country at large. This in turn enabled CyberWatch to impact numerous higher education institutions, students, faculty, and both public and private sector organizations across the U.S. Community engagement with CyberWatch resources and programs continually exceed industry benchmarks. In addition, CyberWatch has fulfilled the sustainability requirement of the current and previous grants.

Sample CyberWatch outcomes include:

  • Continued voice of community colleges in national cybersecurity education and workforce development discussions.
  • Far reaching and effective stakeholder engagement with resource dissemination and outreach campaigns. Social media engagement is over 100 times better than industry benchmarks. Less than 5% of industry brands top the LinkedIn engagement with CyberWatch resources, according to Rival IQ. 
  • New initiatives: Community College Cyber Summit; Cybersecurity Skills Journal: Practice and Research; Innovations in Cybersecurity Education awards & recognition program; monthly Webcast Series; National Cybersecurity Student Association; Digital Press; Virtual Brown Bag Lunch program.   
  • Serving underrepresented groups through partnerships with the Women in Cybersecurity; National Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science; Cyber and STEAM Global Innovation Alliance; Information Systems Security Association Women in Security Special Interest Group; and minority serving institutions.
  • World-Leading cybersecurity competitions: Mid-Atlantic Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition and National Cyber League.
  • National curriculum efforts: Cloud-based lab platform with hands-on lab exercises; Curriculum Standards Panels; model degrees, certificates, technical courses; e-Books, with supporting instructional materials; and annual Resource Guide: National CyberWatch Center’s Cybersecurity Curriculum Guide: A Complete Solution for Higher Education Institutions.
  • Strategic and continued growth: Membership: exponential growth to over 400 academic institutions and over 15,000 program participants. Curriculum: similar growth in model degree programs (from one to seven over 12 years); certificates (from one to 12 over 12 years); technical courses (from 7 to 34 over 12 years); hands-on practice and challenge labs (from 45 to 400+ over eight years). Community College Cyber Summit attendance (from 189 to 516 over five years). Cybersecurity competition participation (from 1,368 to 3,290 in four years).
  • Sample of ongoing partnerships: Association for Computing Machinery Committee for Computing Education in Community Colleges; CompTIA; Infosec Learning; National Center for the Biotechnology Workforce, National Cybersecurity Training & Education Center; National Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science; Raytheon Technologies; Regional Center for Nuclear Education and Training; Women in Cybersecurity.

CyberWatch has contributed to the cybersecurity community by fostering, disseminating, and researching effective practices in cybersecurity education, training, and job performance. Capacity building programs include: Curriculum models; competitive awards (e.g., Innovations in Cybersecurity Education program); Cybersecurity Skills Development Workshop training programs for faculty, students, and practitioners; and member services to include the management of CyberWatch academic institutions and the National Cybersecurity Student Association. Dissemination programs include: Instructional resources; e-Books; resource guides; conferences; workshops; webcasts; and media communications. Research programs produced white papers, reports, and the Cybersecurity Skills Journal, which are published by the NCC Digital Press. Each of these programs convene and collaborate with stakeholders throughout the cybersecurity community and with the public at large.

In sum, CyberWatch is proud of its accomplishments since its inception in 2005. The center's impressive record proves that it is well positioned as a continual resource for cybersecurity technician education and training, as well as advancing community college cybersecurity education in achieving its mission, “Providing cybersecurity education solutions for the nation.” CyberWatch's proven management structure and continuing world-class personnel provide the necessary ingredients for ongoing success. And finally, the center's past sustainability successes and future plans provide a path for ongoing viability of the center into the foreseeable future.


Last Modified: 12/13/2023
Modified by: David H Tobey

    David H Tobey
    2022-23 CyberWatch resource users
  • CyberWatch LinkedIn Engagement more than triples the average brand, according to Rival IQ. Our top posts consistently average 16.19% engagement rates vs. average brand engagement of 4.73%. Moreover, Rival IQ reports that less than 5% of brands are able to double the benchmark engagement rate.
    CyberWatch Center Digital Press
    Creative Commons
    David H Tobey
    LinkedIn Engagement
  • The CyberWatch Communicator eNewsletter has open rates averaging 34.6% that exceed the Education industry benchmark of between 25-28%, according to Campaign Monitor.
    CyberWatch Center Digital Press
    Creative Commons
    David H Tobey
    CyberWatch Communicator eNewsletter Open and Click-Through Rates
  • Top 3 CyberWatch Tweets show the community engages with CyberWatch tweets more than 100 times more than the best social media posts. Engagement rates between 0.0-0.09% are considered good engagement. Community engagement with CyberWatch top tweets average engagement is 9.16%!
    CyberWatch Center Digital Press
    Creative Commons
    David H Tobey
    Top 3 CyberWatch Tweets
